title: 106_s1278
content: The Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 is amended to change the composition, operation, and duties of the Board of Directors. Section 2 regarding membership, operation, and duties of the Board of Directors is revised. The Board of Directors of the Corporation shall consist of 9 members appointed by the President with Senate approval, who must be residents of the service area. The Board members will select a chairman, and to be eligible for appointment, individuals must be U.S. citizens with relevant experience in corporate management, not employed by the Corporation. The Board of Directors of the Corporation consists of 9 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members must not be Corporation employees, have no financial interest in competing businesses, and support the Act. No more than 5 members can be from the same political party. The President considers recommendations from public officials when appointing Board members. The Board of Directors of the Corporation consists of 9 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members must not be Corporation employees, have no financial interest in competing businesses, and support the Act. The President considers recommendations from public officials when appointing Board members, including Governors, citizens, organizations, and congressional delegations. Members serve 5-year terms, with initial appointments varying in length. Qualified members reflecting the diversity and needs of the service area are sought. The Board of Directors of the Corporation consists of 9 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members serve 5-year terms, with initial appointments varying in length. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and members may be reappointed for an additional term. Six members of the Board constitute a quorum. The Board of Directors consists of 9 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members serve 5-year terms, with initial appointments varying in length. Six members constitute a quorum for business transactions. Board members receive a stipend of $25,000 per year, plus compensation for duties performed. The Board of Directors oversees the Corporation's goals, objectives, and policies, assisting the CEO in achieving them and preparing for industry changes. Members receive a stipend and compensation for duties performed. The Board of Directors is responsible for ensuring goals are achieved, approving budgets, establishing compensation plans, and ensuring compliance with laws. They also approve salaries and benefits for managers and technical personnel. An audit committee is created to recommend an external auditor. The audit committee is responsible for reviewing reports from the external auditor and making recommendations to the Board. They also conduct public hearings on issues affecting electric ratepayers and establish electricity rate schedules. The Board is responsible for establishing the electricity rate schedule and must meet at least 4 times a year. They appoint a chief executive officer who must be a U.S. citizen with management experience in large organizations and no financial interest in public-utility corporations. The Board appoints a chief executive officer who must have no financial interest in public-utility corporations. The CEO's tenure is at the pleasure of the Board, and a compensation plan is approved based on industry standards. The compensation plan for employees in public utilities considers education, experience, responsibility levels, and recruitment needs. Salaries are determined by the chief executive officer for positions at or below level IV after submission to Congress and a public review period. The Tennessee Valley Authority's board of directors' compensation plan states that salaries for employees should not exceed the annual rate for positions at level IV of the Executive Schedule. Current board members appointed before the amendment will continue to serve until the end of their term but cannot be reappointed. SEC. 2 of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 is amended to change the manner of appointment of staff by the Chief Executive Officer with the advice and consent of the Board. SEC. 3 includes conforming amendments. SEC. 3 of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 is amended to change references from "board" to "Board of Directors" and includes provisions for audits and administrative accounts. The Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 is amended to change references to the "board" to the "Board of Directors" and includes provisions for audits and administrative accounts. The amendments made by this Act take effect on May 18, 2000, with the appointment of 7 additional members to the Board of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
